## One way

```{r}
#| label: tabs-and-headers
#| results: asis
for(bb in c("Danielle", "Jasmine")) {
  dat <- babynames |> filter(name == bb)
  pic <- ggplot(dat, aes(year, prop, fill = sex)) + geom_col()
  print(quarto_section(.title = bb, .level = 3))
  print(quarto_tabset("Plot" = pic, "Data" = dat, .level = 4))
}
```

## Or another

```{r}
#| label: tabs-and-headers-2
#| results: asis
dat <- list()
pic <- list()
bbs <- paste0("Dan", c("", "i", "ni", "ny", "iel", "ielle", "iela"))
for(bb in bbs) {
  dat[[bb]] <- babynames |> filter(name == bb)
  pic[[bb]] <- ggplot(dat[[bb]], aes(year, prop, fill = sex)) + geom_col()
}
quarto_output(
  quarto_tabsec(.title = "Plot", .content = pic, .level = 3),
  quarto_tabsec(.title = "Data", .content = dat, .level = 3)
)
```

## Passing markdown directly

```{r}
#| label: raw-1
#| results: asis
quarto_markdown(prideprejudice[8:16], .sep = " ")
```

```{r}
#| label: raw-2
#| results: asis
quarto_markdown(
  "- this ends up being",
  "- a markdown list", 
  "- with **formatting**",
  .sep = "\n"
)
```

## Divs and spans

```{r}
#| label: div
#| results: asis
quarto_div(
  "This is some margin text.", 
  "The strings are pasted together,",
  "with a separator",
  .class = "column-margin",
  .sep = " "
)
quarto_div(
  "This is a callout note.",
  "The idea is the same, really.",
  .class = "callout-note",
  .sep = " "
)
```

```{r}
#| label: span
#| results: asis
quarto_paragraph(
  quarto_span(.content = "this is plain text"),
  quarto_span(.content = "this is highlighted", .class = "mark"),
  quarto_span(.content = "this is underlined", .class = "underline"),
  .sep = ", "
)
```
